            </perform>
        </rule>

description:
This ruleset provides analysis of JBoss SOA Platform 5 applications and provides information on
            how to migrate these to Red Hat JBoss Fuse Service Works

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="soa-p-5-01000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile as="xmlclass" matches="//*[local-name()='action' and not(starts-with(@class, 'org.jboss.soa.esb.actions')) and not(starts-with(@class, 'org.jboss.soa.esb.smooks')) and windup:matches(@class, '{javaclassname}')]/@class"/>
                <javaclass as="javaclasses" in="{javaclassname}" references="org.jboss.soa.esb.message.Message"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <iteration over="xmlclass">
                    <hint effort="3" title="JBoss ESB 5 Action Handler">
                        <message>
                            <![CDATA[
                                Custom action classes should be migrated to CDI Beans in Fuse Service Works. These beans can be defined as services or called directly from a Camel route.

                                For more information, see the [Action Class Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/action-class-migration.md).
                            ]]>
                        </message>
                        <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                    </hint>
                </iteration>
                <iteration over="javaclasses">
                    <classification effort="3" issue-display-mode="detail-only" title="JBoss ESB 5 Action Handler">
                        <description>
                            <![CDATA[
                                Custom action classes should be migrated to CDI Beans in Fuse Service Works. These beans can be defined as services or called directly from a Camel route.
                            ]]>
                        </description>

                        <!-- TODO: Replace with a link to the customer portal once one is available -->
                        <link href="https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/action-class-migration.md" title="Action Class Migration"/>
                        <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                    </classification>
                </iteration>
            </perform>
            <where param="javaclassname">
                <matches pattern=".*"/>
            </where>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-02000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="/jbossesb-deployment"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <classification effort="13" issue-display-mode="all" title="JBoss ESB Deployment Descriptor">
                    <!-- This needs documentation... I cannot find documentation on migrating this file -->
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </classification>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-03000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="/*[local-name()='jbossesb']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <classification effort="7" issue-display-mode="all" title="JBoss ESB Pipeline Configuration">
                    <!-- TODO: Replace with a link to the customer portal once one is available -->
                    <link href="https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/action-pipeline-migration.md" title="Action Pipeline Migration"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </classification>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-04000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="/*[local-name()='smooks-resource-list']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <classification effort="0" issue-display-mode="detail-only" title="Smooks Configuration">
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_2_Smooks/" title="Smooks Development Guide"/>
                    <tag>smooks</tag>
                </classification>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-05000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='jms-listener' and @is-gateway='true']/@name"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <iteration>
                    <hint effort="3" title="JMS Gateway Listener">
                        <message>
                            <![CDATA[
                                This listener requires a composite service binding in Fuse Service Works. The configuration for a JCA or JMS binding can be found in the jms-bus definition
                                associated with this listener.

                                For additional information, see the
                                [Gateway Listener Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/gateway-listener-migration.md).
                            ]]>
                        </message>
                        <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                    </hint>
                </iteration>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-06000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='jms-listener' and (not(@is-gateway) or @is-gateway='false')]/@name"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="1" title="ESB-Aware Listener (non-gateway)">
                    <message>An ESB-aware listener is no longer required in Fuse Service Works.</message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-07000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='service']/@name"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="JBoss SOA-P Service">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            Each <service> definition in SOA-P 5 represents a service which can be
                            called from outside the application through an ESB listner.  The
                            equivalent definition in Fuse Service Works is a composite service.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Service Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/service-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-08000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='actions']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="5" title="JBoss SOA-P Action Pipeline">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            The logic and execution flow of a service in SOA-P 5 is defined in an
                            action processing pipeline. This logic is
                            contained within a service component definition and expressed
                            using any of the available implementation types in Fuse Service Works.

                            For additional information see: the [Action Pipeline Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/action-pipeline-migration.md)
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-09000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='hibernate-bus']/@busid"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="13" title="Service Binding: Hibernate Bus">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            Although Camel has both Hibernate and JPA components that are
                            useful in consuming records, there isn't any support for Hibernate events.

                            To migrate this to SwitchYard you may have to
                            build a custom SwitchYard component using Hibernate
                            listeners, or redesign your requirements to leverage the
                            existing Camel components available (Hibernate/JPA/SQL)
                            in this area.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-10000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='jms-bus']/@busid"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="JMS Bus Definition">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A jms-bus definition can be converted to a JMS or JCA gateway
                            binding on a composite service in SwitchYard. If the jms-bus
                            configuration is used for a non-gateway listener, it does not
                            need to be migrated to Fuse Service Works.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [JMS Bus Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/jms-bus-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-11000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='ftp-bus']/@busid"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="FTP Bus Definition">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A ftp-bus definition can be converted to a FTP gateway
                            binding on a composite service in SwitchYard.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [FTP Bus Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/ftp-bus-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-12000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='camel-bus']/@busid"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="Camel Bus Definition">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A camel-bus definition can be converted to a Camel gateway
                            binding on a composite service in SwitchYard.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Camel Bus Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/camel-bus-migration.md)
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>camel</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-13000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='udp-listener']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="UDP Listener Configuration">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A UDP Listener definition can be converted to a TCP/UDP
                            gateway binding on a composite service in SwitchYard.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Gateways.html#sect-TCP_UDP" title="TCP/UDP Gateway"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-14000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='jms-jca-provider']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="JMS JCA Provider">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A jms-jca-provider definition can be converted to a JCA
                            gateway binding on a composite service in Fuse Service Works.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Gateways.html#sect-JCA" title="JCA Gateway Binding"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-5-15000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='http-provider']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="HTTP Provider">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A http-provider definition can be converted to a HTTP gateway
                            binding on a composite service in Fuse Service Works.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Gateway Listener Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/gateway-listener-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>soa-p</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-16000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='cron-schedule']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="Cron Schedule">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A cron-schedule definition can be converted to a Quartz
                            gateway binding on a composite service in Fuse Service Works.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Cron Scheduler Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/cron-schedule-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-17000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='ftp-listener' and @is-gateway='true']/@name"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="FTP Gateway Listener">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            This listener requires a composite service binding in Fuse Service Works. The configuration for a FTP binding
                            can be found in the ftp-bus definition associated with this listener.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Gateway Listener Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/gateway-listener-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-18000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='camel-gateway']/@busidref"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="Camel Gateway Listener">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            This gateway requires a composite service binding in Fuse Service Works.
                            The configuration for a Camel binding can be found in the camel-bus definition associated
                            with this listener.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Gateway Listener Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/gateway-listener-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                    <tag>camel</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-19000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='http-gateway']/@name"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="HTTP Gateway Listener">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A <http-gateway> can be replaced in Fuse Service Works by a http binding added to your composite service.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [HTTP Gateway Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/http-gateway-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-20000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.smooks.SmooksAction']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="Smooks Transformation Action">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            Fuse Service Works uses a <transform> to replace the invocation
                            of as SmooksAction to transform message content. You most likely will want to use a Smooks transform
                            to specify your Smooks configuration and from/to types.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>smooks</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-21000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='property' and @name='smooksConfig']/@name"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="Smooks Config">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In a Fuse Service Works Smooks transform, you can specify your Smooks configuration with the "config" attribute.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>smooks</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-22000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.smooks.SmooksAction']/*[local-name()='property' and @name='resultType']"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="Smooks Result Type">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            Fuse Service Works uses a <transform> to replace the invocation of as SmooksAction
                            to transform message content. You most likely will want to use a Smooks transform
                            to specify your Smooks configuration and from/to types.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>smooks</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-23000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.soap.proxy.SOAPProxy']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB SOAP Proxy">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            Instead of the JBoss ESB SOAPProxy action which transforms a specified WSDL and rewrites the address to the JBoss ESB server,
                            Fuse Service Works relies on Camel's routing capability to forward requests from a proxying service to the source.
                            Create a proxy service and a reference to the original service, and then use Camel to route them.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [SOAPProxy Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/soap-proxy.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-24000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.SystemPrintln']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB SystemPrintln Action">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to log your message (or a static logging message), you may want to create a Bean service which logs the message in the manner you wish, or you can use Camel routing to log static
                            logging messages.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Action Class Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/action-class-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-25000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.StaticRouter']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB Static Router">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to configure static routes for your message in
                            Fuse Service Works, you should use Camel's routing (either through Java DSL routes or route.xml).

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Action Class Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/action-class-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-26000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.routing.JMSRouter']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB JMS Router">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the JMSRouter in Fuse Service Works, you should use a JMS binding. You may need to review the options for JMS bindings in
                            Fuse Service Works if you are using the unwrap property.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Action Class Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/action-class-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-27000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.TestMessageStore']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB Test Message Store">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            TestMessageStore is an out-of-the-box ESB action that is used in JBoss Application Server
                            container tests to store a message with some form of logging - to a file, JMX, etc. TestMessageStore is used throughout
                            the JBoss ESB sample projects to help test the results of processed messages.

                            Fuse Service Works is able to leverage Arquillian to do container testing, so TestMessageStore is not
                            necessary for testing. This action should simply be removed during the migration.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-28000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.scripting.GroovyActionProcessor']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB GroovyActionProcessor">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            The GroovyActionProcessor action executes a Groovy script. You can duplicate this functionality in
                            Fuse Service Works through Camel routing (both Java and XML.)

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Camel Scripting Guide](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Service_Implementations.html#Using_Scripting_Languages).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-29000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.services.jbpm.actions.BpmProcessor']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB BpmProcessor">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            The BpmProcessor makes calls to jBPM 3 through the jBPM command API. Fuse Service Works supports jBPM 5, so you will need
                            to migrate your existing workflow from jBPM 3 to jBPM 5 and use a Fuse Service Works BPM implementation.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [BPM Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/bpm_migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-30000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='fs-bus']/@busid"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB Filesystem Bus">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            A fs-bus definition can be converted to a Camel binding on a composite service in Fuse Service Works.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Gateway Listener Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/gateway-listener-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-31000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.Notifier']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="7" title="ESB Notifier Action">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses notifiers to transform ESB aware messages to a format that ESB-unaware services can handle. Fuse Service Works uses bi-directional gateways to transfer messages
                            via its service bindings.

                            A JBoss ESB Notifier should be converted to a Fuse Service Works Service Binding.

                            For example:

                            ```xml
                            <service category="routerToFile" name="FileRouterListener" description="Static route file destination">
                                <actions mep="OneWay">
                                    <action name="notificationAction" class="org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.Notifier">
                                        <property name="okMethod" value="notifyOK"/>
                                        <property name="notification-details">
                                            <NotificationList type="ok">
                                                <target class="NotifyFiles">
                                                    <file append="false" URI="/tmp/HelloWorldFileNotifierTest.log"/>
                                                </target>
                                            </NotificationList>
                                        </property>
                                    </action>
                                </actions>
                            </service>
                            ```


                            Could be translated to:

                            ```xml
                            <sca:reference name="HelloWorld" multiplicity="0..1" promote="MyComponent/HelloWorld">
                                <camel:binding.file>
                                    <camel:directory>/tmp</camel:directory>
                                    <camel:fileName>HelloWorldFileNotifierTest.log</camel:fileName>
                                </camel:binding.file>
                            </sca:reference>
                            <sca:component name="MyComponent">
                                <sca:reference name="HelloWorld">
                                    <sca:interface.wsdl interface="HelloWorld.wsdl#wsdl.porttype(HelloWorld)"/>
                                </sca:reference>
                            </sca:component>
                            ```
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-32000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.converters.ByteArrayToString']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB ByteArrayToString">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses a ByteArrayToString action to do conversion on a message body. In Fuse Service Works
                            you would use Camel to do type conversion.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="http://camel.apache.org/convertbodyto.html" title="Camel convertBodyTo"/>
                    <link href="http://camel.apache.org/type-converter.html" title="Camel Type Converters"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-33000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.converters.LongToDateConverter']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB LongToDateConverter">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses the LongToDateConverter action to do conversion on a message body.

                            In Fuse Service Works you would use Camel to do type conversion.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="http://camel.apache.org/type-converter.html" title="Camel Type Converters"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-34000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.converters.ObjectToCSVString']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB ObjectToCSVString">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses the ObjectToCSVString action to do conversion on a message body. Fuse Service Works
                            would use a Smooks transform or a Camel route to perform this type of conversion.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-35000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.converters.ObjectInvoke']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB ObjectInvoke">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses a ObjectInvoke action to invoke a processor on a message.
                            Fuse Service Works would use a bean component to do this.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Service_Implementations.html#sect-Bean" title="Fuse Service Works Bean Component"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-36000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.converters.ObjectToXStream']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                    <hint effort="3" title="ESB ObjectToXStream">
                        <message>
                            <![CDATA[
                                JBoss ESB uses an ObjectToXStream action to do convert an Object payload to XML using the XStream
                                processor. Fuse Service Works would use a Smooks transform or a Camel route to do this type of conversion.

                                For additional information, see the
                                [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                            ]]>
                        </message>
                        <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                    </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-37000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.converters.XStreamToObject']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB XStreamToObject">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses an XStreamToObject action to convert XML in a payload to an object using the XStream processor.
                            Fuse Service Works would use Smooks transform or a Camel route transform to do this type of conversion.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-38000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.transformation.xslt.XsltAction']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB XsltAction">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses the XsltAction action to transform documents in a payload. Fuse Service Works would use Camel to do this type of
                            conversion.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-39000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.converters.SmooksTransformer']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB SmooksTransformer">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            Fuse Service Works uses a <transform> to replace the invocation of a SmooksTransformer to transform message content.
                            You will need to use a Smooks transform to specify your Smooks configuration and from/to types.

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Transformation Migration Guide](https://github.com/windup/soa-migration/blob/master/advice/transformation-migration.md).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_2_Smooks/" title="Smooks Development Guide"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-40000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.MessagePersister']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB MessagePersister">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses the MessagePersister action to persist a message. Fuse Service Works would use
                            a [SQL reference binding](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Gateways.html#sect-SQL) to accomplish something similar.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-41000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.EJBProcessor']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB EJBProcessor">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses the EJBProcessor action to invoke a stateless session bean with the contents of a message.
                            Similar things can be achieved in Fuse Service Works through the use ofa bean service.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Service_Implementations.html#sect-Bean" title="Fuse Service Works Bean Component"/>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-42000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.scripting.ScriptingAction']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB ScriptingAction">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            The ScriptingAction executes a script using the BeanScriptingFramework. You can duplicate this functionality in Fuse Service Works
                            through Camel routing (both Java and XML.)

                            For additional information, see the
                            [Camel Scripting Guide](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Service_Implementations.html#Using_Scripting_Languages).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-43000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and windup:matches(@class, 'org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.{javaclassname}')]/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB {javaclassname}">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            JBoss ESB uses the {javaclassname} action to aggregate a message sequence into a single aggregated message.
                            Fuse Service Works would make use of Camel routing and Camel's aggregator to accomplish this.

                            For more information, see the
                            [Camel Aggregator Documentation](http://camel.apache.org/aggregator.html).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
            <where param="javaclassname">
                <matches pattern="(StreamingAggregator)|(Aggregator)"/>
            </where>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-44000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.routing.http.HttpRouter']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB HTTP Router">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the HttpRouter in JBoss ESB, you should use a HTTP reference binding.

                            Further documentation is available in the
                            [Fuse Service Works Developer Guide](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Gateways.html#sect-HTTP).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-45000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.routing.email.EmailRouter']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB Email Router">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the EmailRouter in Fuse Service Works, you should use a mail reference binding.

                            Further documentation is available in the
                            [Fuse Service Works Developer Guide](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Gateways.html#sect-Mail).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-46000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.ContentBasedRouter']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB ContentBasedRouter">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the ContentBasedRouter in Fuse Service Works, you should use Camel to route messages.

                            A good example of this functionality can be found in the quickstarts project in the [rules-camel-jbr
                            quickstart](https://github.com/jboss-switchyard/quickstarts/tree/master/rules-camel-cbr).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-47000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.StaticWiretap']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB StaticWiretap">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the StaticWiretap in Fuse Service Works, you should use a
                            [Camel Wiretap](http://camel.apache.org/wire-tap.html) to perform this action.
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-48000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.StaticRouter']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB Static Router">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the StaticRouter in Fuse Service Works, you should use Camel to route messages.

                            Further information is available in the [Camel Integration Patterns Documentation](http://camel.apache.org/enterprise-integration-patterns.html).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-49000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.soap.SOAPProcessor']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB SOAPProcessor">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the SOAPProcessor you should use a SOAP reference binding in Fuse Service Works.

                            For more information, see the
                            [Fuse Service Works Development Guide](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Gateways.html#sect-SOAP).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="soa-p-50000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*[local-name()='action' and @class='org.jboss.soa.esb.actions.soap.SOAPClient']/@class"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint effort="3" title="ESB SOAPClient">
                    <message>
                        <![CDATA[
                            In order to replace the use of the SOAPClient in Fuse Service Works, you should use a SOAP reference binding.

                            For more information, see the
                            [Fuse Service Works Development Guide](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_JBoss_Fuse_Service_Works/6.0/html/Development_Guide_Volume_1_SwitchYard/chap-Gateways.html#sect-SOAP).
                        ]]>
                    </message>
                    <tag>jboss-esb</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

description: Verify the version of the Spring Boot framework is compatible with those supported by Red Hat Runtimes

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="springboot-00001" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <!-- rule condition, when it could be fired -->
            <when>
                <dependency artifactId="{*}" groupId="org.springframework.boot" toVersion="1.6.0"/>
            </when>
            <!-- rule operation, what to do if it is fired -->
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="3" title="Unsupported version of Spring Boot">
                    <message>Spring Boot has to be updated to Spring Boot 2.0 before being able to be migrated to a version supported by Red Hat Runtimes</message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/articles/3349341" title="RHOAR Spring Boot Supported Configurations"/>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/articles/3348731" title="RHOAR Component Details Overview"/>
                    <link href="https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.0-Migration-Guide" title="Spring Boot 2.0 Migration Guide"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="springboot-00002" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <!-- rule condition, when it could be fired -->
            <when>
                <dependency artifactId="{*}" fromVersion="2.0.0" groupId="org.springframework.boot" toVersion="2.1.1.RELEASE"/>
            </when>
            <!-- rule operation, what to do if it is fired -->
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="1" title="Unsupported version of Spring Boot">
                    <message>Spring Boot has to be updated to a version supported by Red Hat Runtimes</message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/articles/3349341" title="RHOAR Spring Boot Supported Configurations"/>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/articles/3348731" title="RHOAR Component Details Overview"/>
                    <link href="https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/wiki/Spring-Boot-2.1-Release-Notes#upgrading-from-spring-boot-20" title="Spring Boot 2.1 - Upgrading from Spring Boot 2.0"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

description: Verify the version of the Spring Boot framework is compatible with those supported by Red Hat Runtimes

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="springboot-associated-00001" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <dependency artifactId="amqp-10-jms-spring-boot-starter" groupId="org.amqphub.spring" toVersion="2.0.9"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="1" title="Unsupported version of AMQP SpringBoot starter">
                    <message>Check the links below for the Red Hat Runtimes supported version of AMQP SpringBoot starter</message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/articles/3349341" title="RHOAR Spring Boot Supported Configurations"/>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/articles/3348731" title="RHOAR Component Details Overview"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="springboot-associated-00002" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <dependency artifactId="cxf-spring-boot-starter-jaxrs" groupId="org.apache.cxf"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="1" title="Unsupported version of CXF JAXRS SpringBoot starter">

description: This is a ruleset for Windows operating system specific rules while migrating to Linux operating system.

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="os-specific-00001" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <filecontent filename="{*}.{extensions}" pattern="{pattern}"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="1" title="Windows file system path">
                    <message>This file system path is Microsoft Windows platform dependent. It needs to be replaced with a Linux-style path.</message>
                    <tag>ms-windows</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
            <where param="extensions">
                <matches pattern="(java|properties|jsp|jspf|tag|xml|txt)"/>
            </where>
            <where param="pattern">
                <matches pattern="[A-z]:([\\][^\n\t]+)+|(\\\\([^\\\,\n\t]+)\\\S+)+"/>
            </where>
        </rule>

description: This ruleset gives hints to migrate from SpringBoot Metrics to Quarkus Microprofile Metrics extension

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="springboot-metrics-to-quarkus-0100" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <dependency artifactId="micrometer-core" groupId="io.micrometer"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="5" title="Replace the Micrometer dependency with Quarkus Microprofile 'metrics' extension">
                    <message>
                        Replace the Micrometer dependency with Quarkus Microprofile 'metrics' extension.  
                        Usually this is a transitive dependency brought by `org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-actuator` and has to be replaced by `io.quarkus:quarkus-smallrye-metrics` artifact
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/microprofile-metrics" title="Quarkus metrics"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="springboot-metrics-to-quarkus-0200" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="io.micrometer.core.instrument.{*}">
                    <location>IMPORT</location>
                </javaclass>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="5" title="Replace the Micrometer code with Microprofile Metrics code">
                    <message>
                        Replace the Micrometer code with Microprofile Metrics code
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/microprofile-metrics" title="Quarkus metrics"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="springboot-metrics-to-quarkus-0300" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="io.micrometer.core.annotation.Timed">
                    <location>IMPORT</location>
                </javaclass>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="5" title="Replace the Micrometer Timed annotation with Microprofile Timed annotation">
                    <message>Replace the Micrometer Timed annotation with Microprofile Timed annotation</message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/microprofile-metrics" title="Quarkus metrics"/>
                    <link href="https://www.javadoc.io/doc/io.micrometer/micrometer-core/latest/io/micrometer/core/annotation/Timed.html" title="Micrometer Timed JavaDoc"/>
                    <link href="https://www.javadoc.io/doc/org.eclipse.microprofile/microprofile/latest/org/eclipse/microprofile/metrics/annotation/Timed.html" title="Microprofile Timed JavaDoc"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="springboot-metrics-to-quarkus-0310" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="io.micrometer.core.annotation.{*}">
                    <location>IMPORT</location>
                </javaclass>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <iteration>
                    <when>
                        <not>
                            <has-hint/>
                        </not>
                    </when>
                    <perform>
                        <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="5" title="Replace the Micrometer metric annotation with Microprofile metric annotation">
                            <message>Replace the Micrometer metric annotation with Microprofile metric annotation</message>
                            <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/microprofile-metrics" title="Quarkus metrics"/>
                        </hint>
                    </perform>
                </iteration>
            </perform>
        </rule>

description: This ruleset gives hints to migrate from SpringBoot Integration to Quarkus

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="springboot-integration-to-quarkus-00000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <dependency artifactId="spring-integration-core" groupId="org.springframework.integration"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="7" title="SpringBoot Integration is not supported.">
                    <message>
                        SpringBoot Integration is not supported. A migration to Apache Camel is mandatory.  
                        Spring dependency `org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-integration` needs to move to `org.apache.camel.quarkus:camel-quarkus-parent`.  
                        Spring Integration Flows must be recoded into Apache Camel Routes.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/camel" title="Quarkus Apache Camel"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="springboot-integration-to-quarkus-00010" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <xmlfile matches="//*/int:channel">
                    <namespace prefix="int" uri="http://www.springframework.org/schema/integration"/>
                </xmlfile>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="5" title="SpringBoot Integration flows are not supported.">
                    <message>
                        SpringBoot Integration flows are not supported. A migration to Apache Camel route is mandatory.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/camel" title="Quarkus Apache Camel"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="springboot-integration-to-quarkus-00020" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="org.springframework.integration.dsl.IntegrationFlow">
                  <location>IMPORT</location>
                </javaclass>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="5" title="SpringBoot IntegrationFlow class usage is not supported.">
                    <message>
                        SpringBoot IntegrationFlow class usage is not supported. A migration to Apache Camel route using From is mandatory.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/camel" title="Quarkus Apache Camel"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

description: This ruleset gives hints to migrate from SpringBoot Shell to Quarkus picocli extension

                <project>
                    <artifact artifactId="spring-shell-core" groupId="org.springframework.shell"/>
                </project>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="3" title="Replace the SpringBoot Shell artifact with Quarkus 'picocli' extension">
                    <message>
                        Replace the SpringBoot Shell artifacts with Quarkus `picocli` extension

                        Add Quarkus dependency `io.quarkus:quarkus-picocli`

                        PicoCli provides command-line mode like Spring Shell but does not reuse the Spring interfaces
                        therefore re-coding is also required to use the appropriate PicoCli interfaces.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/picocli" title="Quarkus Command Mode with Picocli Guide"/>
                    <link href="https://spring.io/projects/spring-shell" title="Spring Shell Guide"/>
                </hint>

                        Replace the SpringBoot Dependency Injection artifact with Quarkus `spring-di` extension

                        Spring DI is in spring-beans artifact brought transitively by any `org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-*` dependency
                        Add Quarkus dependency `io.quarkus:quarkus-spring-di`
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/spring-di" title="Quarkus DI Guide"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

description: This ruleset gives hints to migrate from Spring MVC to Quarkus

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="springboot-webmvc-to-quarkus-00000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <file filename="{filenameParameter}-{*}.jar"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="13" title="Spring MVC is not supported by Quarkus">
                    <message>
                        Spring MVC is not supported by Quarkus

                        Code relying on the spring-webmvc.jar or spring-webflux.jar
                        cannot currently be run in Quarkus
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://quarkus.io/guides/spring-web" title="Quarkus Spring Web Guide"/>
                </hint>
            </perform>
            <where param="filenameParameter">
                <matches pattern="(spring-webmvc|spring-webflux)"/>
            </where>
        </rule>

description: This ruleset provides analysis with respect to the migration from OracleJDK to OpenJDK.

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="oracle2openjdk-00000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="javafx.{*}">
                    <location>IMPORT</location>
                </javaclass>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="0" title="JavaFX usage">
                    <message>
                        Currently OpenJFX (open-source implementation of JavaFX) is neither shipped nor supported on RHEL.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/solutions/3299701" title="Knowledge base article about JavaFX support in RHEL"/>
                    <link href="https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1275610" title="RFE to include OpenJFX in RHEL"/>
                    <tag>JavaFX</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="oracle2openjdk-00001" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <or>
                    <javaclass references="{package}.Font">
                        <location>IMPORT</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <!-- covers get/setFont methods -->
                    <javaclass references="{package}.{*}Font{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="javax.swing.{*}.{*}Font{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                </or>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="0" title="Fonts usage">
                    <message>
                        The font library is different in OpenJDK compared to OracleJDK.
                        This means slightly different text layout in some cases.
                        Ensure with tests that the output is still as expected.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2489791" title="Knowledge base article OracleJDK vs. OpenJDK"/>
                    <tag>fonts</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
            <where param="package">
                <matches pattern="(java\.awt|javafx\.scene\.text)"/>
            </where>
        </rule>

<rule id="oracle2openjdk-00002" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="jdk.management.resource.{*}"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="0" title="Resource management API usage">
                    <message>
                        OpenJDK does not support the resource management API for Java.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2489791" title="Knowledge base article OracleJDK vs. OpenJDK"/>
                    <tag>Oracle JDK resource management</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="oracle2openjdk-00003" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="java.awt.Color"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="0" title="Color management usage">
                    <message>
                        OracleJDK used to use KCMS as color mangement system up until JDK7 by default. It switched to Little CMS (LCMS) with JDK8.
                        OpenJDK uses LCMS. If you continued to use KCMS by using the property ``sun.java2d.cmm=sun.java2d.cmm.kcms.KcmsServiceProvider``, remove this property and ensure in your tests that your application still works as expected.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2489791" title="Knowledge base article OracleJDK vs. OpenJDK"/>
                    <tag>JDK color management</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="oracle2openjdk-00004" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="java.awt.{package}{*}">
                    <location>IMPORT</location>
                </javaclass>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="0" title="Java 2D library usage">
                    <message>
                       OpenJDK has its own 2D library, different from the proprietary JDK. This means that its performance may be different.
                       Ensure during your tests that the application behaves as expected.
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2489791" title="Knowledge base article OracleJDK vs. OpenJDK"/>
                    <tag>2D library</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
            <where param="package">
                <matches pattern="(geom|color|font|image|image\.renderable|print)"/>
            </where>
        </rule>

<rule id="oracle2openjdk-00005" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <or>
                    <!--
                        these two will produce some false positives since we can't check explcitely
                        just for respective string values like e.g. "EC"
                    -->
                    <javaclass references="java.security.KeyPairGenerator.getInstance({*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="javax.crypto.KeyAgreement.getInstance({*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="java.security.spec.EC{*}">
                        <location>CONSTRUCTOR_CALL</location>
                        <location>IMPORT</location>
                        <location>INHERITANCE</location>
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                        <location>VARIABLE_DECLARATION</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="java.security.spec.EllipticCurve{*}">
                        <location>CONSTRUCTOR_CALL</location>
                        <location>IMPORT</location>
                        <location>INHERITANCE</location>
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                        <location>VARIABLE_DECLARATION</location>
                    </javaclass>
                </or>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="potential" effort="0" title="Crypto: elliptic curves usage">
                    <message>
                    When on RHEL, OpenJDK uses the NSS crypto library from RHEL instead of the built-in one.

                    This mostly affects elliptic curve cryptography, where OpenJDK supports all of the RHEL curves and none of the others.
                    
                    A list of all cipher suits of NSS in RHEL:

                    * RHEL6: [https://access.redhat.com/articles/1470663](https://access.redhat.com/articles/1470663)
                    * RHEL7: [https://access.redhat.com/articles/1463663](https://access.redhat.com/articles/1463663)
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/solutions/2489791" title="Knowledge base article OracleJDK vs. OpenJDK"/>
                    <tag>crypto</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

description: This ruleset provides analysis of WebLogic proprietary classes and constructs that may require individual attention when migrating to JBoss EAP 6+.

rules.ruleContents:
<rule id="weblogic-01000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="weblogic.time.common.Triggerable">
                    <location>IMPLEMENTS_TYPE</location>
                </javaclass>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <classification effort="0" issue-display-mode="detail-only" title="WebLogic scheduled job">
                    <link href="https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/tutorial/doc/bnboy.html" title="EJB Timer Service"/>
                    <tag>scheduler</tag>
                    <tag>ejb</tag>
                    <tag>timer</tag>
                    <tag>weblogic</tag>
                </classification>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="3" title="WebLogic Scheduled Job">
                    <message>
                      <![CDATA[
                      WebLogic scheduled jobs should be migrated to use the standard EJB `javax.ejb.TimerService`.
                      ]]>
                    </message>
                    <link href="https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/tutorial/doc/bnboy.html" title="Java EE 6 - Using TimerService"/>
                    <tag>scheduler</tag>
                    <tag>ejb</tag>
                    <tag>timer</tag>
                    <tag>weblogic</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="weblogic-02000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="weblogic.utils.StringUtils.{*}"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="1" title="WebLogic StringUtils usage">
                    <message>Replace with the `StringUtils` class from Apache Commons.</message>
                    <link href="https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/" title="Apache Commons Lang"/>
                    <tag>weblogic</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="weblogic-03000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="weblogic.apache.xml.{*}"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="1" title="WebLogic specific Apache XML package">
                    <message>
                        Code using this package should be replaced with code using the org.apache.xml package from [Apache Xerces](http://xerces.apache.org/).
                    </message>
                    <tag>weblogic</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="weblogic-04000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.{classname}"/>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="1" title="WebLogic TransactionManager usage">
                    <message>Replace with the Java EE standard [javax.transaction.TransactionManager](http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/transaction/TransactionManager.html)</message>
                    <link href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/JBoss_Enterprise_Application_Platform/6.4/html/Development_Guide/chap-Java_Transaction_API_JTA.html" title="JBoss EAP 6.4 - Java Transaction API (JTA)"/>
                    <link href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/transaction/TransactionManager.html" title="Java Enterprise Edition 7 - TransactionManager"/>
                    <tag>transactions</tag>
                    <tag>weblogic</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
            <where param="classname">
                <matches pattern="(Client)*TransactionManager"/>
            </where>
        </rule>

<rule id="weblogic-05000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <or>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.TransactionManager.resume{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.TransactionManager.forceResume{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.ClientTransactionManager.resume{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.ClientTransactionManager.forceResume{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                </or>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="1" title="WebLogic TransactionManager usage of resume method">
                    <message>Replace with the Java EE standard method `javax.transaction.TransactionManager.resume(Transaction tx)`.</message>
                    <tag>transactions</tag>
                    <tag>weblogic</tag>
                </hint>
            </perform>
        </rule>

<rule id="weblogic-06000" xmlns="http://windup.jboss.org/schema/jboss-ruleset">
            <when>
                <or>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.TransactionManager.suspend{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.TransactionManager.forceSuspend{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.ClientTransactionManager.suspend{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                    <javaclass references="weblogic.transaction.ClientTransactionManager.forceSuspend{*}">
                        <location>METHOD_CALL</location>
                    </javaclass>
                </or>
            </when>
            <perform>
                <hint category-id="mandatory" effort="1" title="WebLogic TransactionManager usage of suspend method">
                    <message>Replace with the Java EE standard `javax.transaction.TransactionManager.suspend()`</message>
                    <tag>transactions</tag>
                    <tag>weblogic</tag>
                </hint>
